abstract.p: We report a case of gallbladder perforation (GBP) in a patient with right upper quadrant pain and a positive Murphy's sign, a previous history of cholelithiasis and co-morbidities. We compare the diagnosis of GBP using the ‘hole-sign’ on ultrasound with the literature for contrast-enhanced ultrasound, computed tomography and magnetic resonance imaging.

sec.p: Gallbladder perforation (GBP) is a rare but life-threatening complication of acute cholecystitis.1,2 It is often related to cholelithiasis due to the abrasion of the gallbladder wall from mobile gallstones.3 Other risk factors include cardiovascular disease, diabetes, infection and increasing age.4 GBP occurs in 5–10% of patients with acute cholecystitis and is more prevalent in men.2,5 It has a mortality rate of up to 70%, which is decreasing, possibly due to improved health-care services.5–8 The high mortality rate is thought to be related to delay in surgical intervention, most likely due to difficulties in differentiating GBP symptoms (such as abdominal tenderness, guarding and a positive Murphy's sign) from acute cholecystitis.6,9,10 GBPs have been classified by Niemeier as three types; acute perforation with pericholecystic fluid (Type I), subacute perforation with pericholecystic abscess (Type II) and chronic perforation with the formation of cholecystoenteric fistula (Type III).11–13
Diagnosis of GBP can be achieved using ultrasound, computed tomography (CT) and surgical exploration.6,13

We report a case of GBP in a patient with right upper quadrant (RUQ) pain and a positive Murphy's sign, a previous history of cholelithiasis and co-morbidities. We compare the diagnosis of GBP using the ‘hole-sign’ on ultrasound with the literature for contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS), CT and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

sec.title: Case
sec.p:
An 81-year-old woman with a history of cholelithiasis presented with RUQ pain, a positive Murphy's sign and pyrexia. The patient's previous history included appendectomy, hysterectomy, aortic valve replacement and a pacemaker in situ. The patient was not diabetic, was a non-smoker and a non-drinker. On admission, blood tests showed an increase in white blood cell count (WCC) of 13.21 k/µL (normal range 4.5–11.0 k/µL), bilirubin of 28 µmol/L (normal range 2–12 µmol/L) and C-reaction protein (CRP) of 62 mg/L (normal limits <10 mg/L). An abdominal ultrasound examination14 was performed using a Phillips iU22 and a 1–5 MHz curvilinear transducer (Philips Medical plc, Best, The Netherlands). Tissue harmonic and compound imaging and XRES™ (adaptive image processing) were used to improve the image quality. The examination demonstrated a thick-walled gallbladder measuring 5 mm, containing echogenic bile and two calculi. The largest calculus measured 19 mm and was situated in the gallbladder neck (Figures 1 and 2). Mild intrahepatic duct dilation and a prominent pancreatic duct were noted. The common bile duct (CBD) was of normal calibre (Figures 3 and 4). The other solid organs were normal. Acute cholecystitis and Mirizzi syndrome were diagnosed. The treatment regimen was conservative management with antibiotics.
Figure 1
Transabdominal ultrasound image demonstrating a longitudinal section through the gallbladder with a 5-mm thickened wall (callipers). Echogenic bile is noted within the gallbladder
Figure 2
Transabdominal ultrasound image demonstrating a longitudinal section of the gallbladder neck with a 19-mm gallstone (callipers). Acoustic shadowing artefact is visualized posteriorly to the stone
Figure 3
Transabdominal ultrasound image demonstrating a transverse section through the left lobe of liver and dilated intrahepatic ducts (callipers). Colour flow Doppler is used to differentiate the ducts from blood vessels. Note the increased thickness and echogenecity of the bile duct walls, further indication of this being a bile duct
Figure 4
Transabdominal ultrasound image demonstrating a longitudinal section of a common bile duct with a normal 5.5 mm calibre (callipers). Colour flow Doppler is used to differentiate the common bile duct from a vessel

Six weeks later the patient was re-admitted with increased RUQ pain and a positive Murphy's sign. Blood tests showed a higher elevated WCC of 18.11 k/µL and a 126 mg/L CRP. Another abdominal scan was performed. This again demonstrated two gallstones and biliary sludge within a thick-walled gallbladder. The pancreatic duct was no longer dilated. A defect in the gallbladder wall was detected with free fluid in the gallbladder fossa (Figure 5). This was reported as a GBP, most likely Type I.11 MRI was considered for further imaging; however, due to the contraindication of a pacemaker, a CT scan was performed, with intravenous contrast using a General Electric LightSpeed VCT (GE Healthcare, Milwaukee, WI, USA). The results confirmed the ultrasound findings (Figure 6).
Figure 5
A transabdominal ultrasound image demonstrating a transverse section through the gallbladder. A ‘hole sign’ is noted as a defect in the gallbladder wall with echo-poor bile leaking out into the pericholecystic region
Figure 6
A computed tomography scan image using intravenous contrast demonstrating a gallstone and pericholecystic fluid

A laparoscopic cholecystectomy was successfully performed and the patient was discharged eight days postsurgery with a follow-up appointment in six weeks. To our knowledge she has no abdominal symptoms.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Cholelithiasis leading to cholecystitis is a recognized cause for GBP, particularly if gallstones are located in the gallbladder neck (Figure 2).3,15 This is thought to be due to compression on the cystic duct and CBD causing dilation, thus compromising the blood flow to the gallbladder.4,6 This causes necrosis of the gallbladder wall which then perforates, allowing bile to leak into the pericholecystic region.9,16 In this case, although the CBD was not dilated, dilation of the intrahepatic and pancreatic ducts suggests that compression may have occurred. GBPs tend to be at the fundus of the gallbladder due to its distal vascularity. However, in this case, perforation occurred proximal to the fundus.10,15

Symptoms preceding GBP can differ in individual cases, and are difficult to differentiate from acute cholecystitis, as in this case. The rate at which a GBP occurs following symptoms can also vary.4,17 This makes early diagnosis of GBP difficult. Few studies have reported the diagnosis of GBP, possibly due to the ambiguity surrounding its presentation.5

sec.title: Imaging
sec.p: Ultrasound is the preliminary investigation for biliary symptoms, as it has a high sensitivity and specificity for identifying biliary pathology, including cholelithiasis, cholecystitis and biliary dilation (Figures 1–3).15 It has the added benefits of being cost-effective, without radiation exposure and can establish a direct Murphy's sign.16 Ultrasound has the capacity to demonstrate dilated intrahepatic ducts, which can be distinguished from vessels using colour flow Doppler (Figure 3), indicating Mirizzi syndrome.7 It could be argued that Figure 3 may be misleading due to the poor Doppler angle, however, dynamic imaging revealed these as dilated intrahepatic ducts.18

The sonographic signs of GBP include combinations of cholelithiasis, cholecystitis, echogenic bile, pericholecystic fluid and a defect in the gallbladder wall (Figures 1–5).4,10 The gallbladder wall defect demonstrated on ultrasound, in this case, is often referred to as the ‘hole-sign’. Most clinical series have found ultrasound to be unsuccessful in diagnosing GBP through the detection of the ‘hole-sign’, with the majority considering CT (sensitivity 50–88%) to be more successful (Figure 6). 6,9,13,15,19 Sood et al.9 demonstrated a defect in the gallbladder wall in 70% of patients using ultrasound, but confirm the superiority of CT, with a sensitivity of 78%.

MRI is superior to both ultrasound and CT for GBP. It identifies the pathology in the same way by demonstrating a disruption in the gallbladder wall, but demarcates it more noticeably. As a result, some advocate MRI as a first line of investigation for biliary pathology, including GBP and cholecystitis.20 MRI was contraindicated in this case on account of a pacemaker in situ, hence the use of CT to confirm the sonographic findings. Had MRI been suitable, it may have been deemed unnecessary, as the risk factors, presenting symptoms and ultrasound alone, would have been diagnostic.5

A recent case report performed CEUS, due to contraindications for CT, and found that it was useful in the detection of GBP.21 CEUS appears to delineate the site of perforation as a non-enhancing region (Figure 7).22 This technique requires further investigation. If successful, it could be used by sonographers, in conjunction with B-mode and Doppler ultrasound, as a low-cost, reproducible method which lacks ionizing radiation.2 This practice, in the context of the notable mortality rates with GBP, suggests further investigations, beyond the ultrasound scan, might be considered an unwarranted delay in patient management and treatment.
Figure 7
‘Hole sign’ demonstrated within gallbladder wall (arrow) indicating gallbladder perforation defect, which is well demarcated using contrast-enhanced ultrasound (reproduced with permission)21

sec.title: Treatment
sec.p: Due to the patient's GBP being Type 1 and the contraindications of the co-morbidities for surgery, the initial management for this patient was conservative treatment.1,2,23,24 However, prolonged conservative treatment has been associated with increased mortality rates.1,2,23,24 With Type II GBP, where an infected abscess is formed, ultrasound-guided aspiration has been recommended prior to cholecystectomy or to relieve symptoms.3,6,12 This technique has also been suggested as an alternative for those who are unsuitable for surgery, much like the patient in this case.13,24 Unfortunately, the CT report for this patient stated that there was no drainable fluid, thus eliminating ultrasound-guided aspiration as a treatment option.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: GBPs are complicated to diagnose both clinically and using imaging. The symptoms of GBPs are the same as other biliary pathology, including cholelithiasis and cholecystitis, and there is no specific time frame in which perforation can occur.
This study demonstrates that using good ultrasound technique and advanced imaging controls allows the diagnosis of GBP by identifying the ‘hole-sign’.
When ultrasound is unsuccessful, CT and MRI are well established complementary modalities, with promising advances of CEUS.
Due to the high mortality rate associated with GBPs, laparoscopic cholecystectomy is the preferred treatment option. However, ultrasound-guided aspiration is a possible alternative.

sec.title: DECLARATIONS
sec.p: Competing interests: None.
